item.title: Gold Rises for Second Day on US Rate-Cut Bets, Dollar Weakness
item.description: Gold climbed for a second day on optimism that the Federal Reserve will resume rate cuts this half, while investors continued to monitor US trade talks before a July 9 tariff deadline.
item.dc:creator: Sybilla Gross

media:content.media:description: One kilogram gold bars. Photographer: Brendon Thorne/Bloomberg

item.title: China Raises Quota for Foreign Investment, Ending 13-Month Pause
item.description: China has increased the amount of money that approved investors can put into overseas assets for the first time since May last year as its relaxes its control over capital outflows.
item.dc:creator: John Liu, April Ma

item.title: Can the Quad Counter China in the Indo-Pacific?
item.description: Australian Foreign Minister Penny Wong is in Washington to meet US Secretary of State Marco Rubio and their Japanese and Indian counterparts for a meeting of the so-called Quad nations. CSIS Senior Adviser and Australia Chair Charles Edel says the Quad plays a critical role in the Indo-Pacific, as the four nations share concerns about China's growing power. Edel discussed Canberra's ties with key allies and the impact of Trump's policies on "Bloomberg: The Asia Trade." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: The Asia Trade 07/01/2025
item.description: "Bloomberg: The Asia Trade" brings you everything you need to know to get ahead as the trading day begins in Asia. Bloomberg TV is live from Tokyo and Sydney with Shery Ahn and Haidi Stroud-Watts, getting insight and analysis from newsmakers and industry leaders on the biggest stories shaping global markets. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Global Stock Rally Extends in Asia, Dollar Steady: Markets Wrap
item.description: Stocks kicked off the second half by building on a record-breaking rally as expectations grow that the US economy will withstand uncertainties from President Donald Trump’s tariff agenda.
item.dc:creator: Anand Krishnamoorthy

item.title: Japan Bonds Rally After Stronger-Than-Average 10-Year Bond Sale
item.description: Demand at Japan’s auction of 10-year government bonds was stronger than the 12-month average, as expectations for rate hikes by the central bank recede and upward pressure on longer-maturity yields eases. The nation’s bonds rallied.
item.dc:creator: Aya Wagatsuma

media:content.media:description: Pedestrians cross an intersection in the Shibuya district of Tokyo. Photographer: Shiho Fukada/Bloomberg

item.title: If Anyone Needs Independence Day, It's the Fed
item.description: Lighten up the pressure on Powell. Trump has a point on lower rates, but not 1%.
item.dc:creator: John Authers

media:content.media:description: Jerome Powell, chairman of the US Federal Reserve, during the Federal Reserve Board open meeting in Washington, DC, US, on Wednesday, June 25, 2025. The Federal Reserve unveiled plans to roll back an important capital rule that big banks have said limits their ability to hold more Treasuries and act as intermediaries in the $29 trillion market. Photographer: Bloomberg/Bloomberg

item.title: Markets Are Learning to Keep Calm and Carry On
item.description: The stock and bond markets remain relaxed despite geopolitical chaos.
item.dc:creator: Mark Gilbert, Marcus Ashworth

media:content.media:description: BURY, ENGLAND - APRIL 12: The price of cushions with the war time slogan 'Keep Calm And Carry On' are reduced in a closing down sale at a Past Times store in Bury which closes down this week on April 12, 2011 in Bury, England. Further hard times on the British high street were predicted today as The British Retail Consortium (BRC) has recorded its worst fall in sales since records began in 1996. (Photo by Christopher Furlong/Getty Images)

item.title: ECB Gets Another ‘Moderate Hawk’ as Dutch Central-Bank Veteran Exits
item.description: Olaf Sleijpen, the European Central Bank’s newest interest-rate setter, is about to continue where his Dutch predecessor left off.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Van Oosterom

media:content.media:description: Olaf Sleijpen Source: De Nederlandsche Bank

item.title: Korean Stocks Surge on Renewed Optimism Over Corporate Reforms
item.description: South Korean stocks jumped Tuesday, making them among the top gainers in Asia, as shares of holding companies rallied on hopes that revisions to the Commercial Act will be approved by the parliament this week.
item.dc:creator: John Cheng

item.title: Taiwan Dollar Surges More Than 2% as Traders Test Central Bank
item.description: The Taiwan dollar surged more than 2% in another day of volatility for the currency, as traders tested the central bank’s tolerance for its strength.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Burgess, Betty Hou

media:content.media:description: Taiwanese one thousand dollar banknotes. Photographer: An Rong Xu/Bloomberg

item.title: Sapura Energy Restructuring in ‘Final Stages,’ Company Says
item.description: Malaysian oil and gas contractor Sapura Energy Bhd.’s restructuring plan to restore financial stability is entering its “final stages,” according to the company’s first-quarter earnings statement.
item.dc:creator: Justina T Lee

item.title: China Enlists Commercial Insurers in Bid to Boost Local Biotechs
item.description: China wants commercial insurance firms to invest in the development of homegrown medicines, Beijing’s latest bid to support its burgeoning biotech and pharmaceutical sector.
item.dc:creator: John Liu, Dong Lyu

media:content.media:description: Vials in a laboratory in Shanghai. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

item.title: Markets Fundamentals Strong: Ten Cap's Jun Bei Lu
item.description: Ten Cap Co-Founder and Lead Portfolio Manager Jun Bei Lu speaks on Bloomberg TV about the challenges facing equity investors in the coming 6 months. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Zinc Drops as Growing Chinese Inventories Point to Weak Demand
item.description: Zinc fell for a second day as a buildup in Chinese stockpiles pointed to tepid demand in the No. 1 consumer of the metal.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Zhu, Winnie Zhu

item.title: Yen Enters Seasonally Strong Month With Help From Weak Dollar
item.description: The yen is starting July with history on its side, having rallied this month for the last five years.
item.dc:creator: Aya Wagatsuma

item.title: Ringgit Rises to Nine-Month High on Bond Inflows, Weaker Dollar
item.description: Malaysia’s ringgit advanced to the strongest level in nine months against the dollar, buoyed by foreign bond inflows and a broad weakness in the US currency.
item.dc:creator: Marcus Wong

item.title: Rural Demand May Boost Indian Consumer Companies This Earning Season
item.description: Before the trading day starts we bring you a digest of the key news and events that are likely to move markets. Today we look at:
item.dc:creator: Chiranjivi Chakraborty

item.title: Oil Falls a Second Day Ahead of OPEC+ Production Quota Decision
item.description: Oil declined for a second day to near its lowest level since early June, with the focus turning to how much OPEC+ will increase output quotas this weekend.
item.dc:creator: Yongchang Chin

media:content.media:description: Crude oil storage tanks at the Juaymah Tank Farm in Saudi Aramco's Ras Tanura oil refinery and oil terminal in Ras Tanura, Saudi Arabia, on Monday, Oct. 1, 2018. Saudi Arabia is seeking to transform its crude-dependent economy by developing new industries, and is pushing into petrochemicals as a way to earn more from its energy deposits.

item.title: Taiwan Life Insurers Caught in Dilemma With Costly FX Hedges
item.description: Taiwan’s life insurers were caught flat-footed when the local dollar surged in May, with the latest data suggesting that elevated hedging costs have hampered efforts to mitigate currency risks.
item.dc:creator: Chien-Hua Wan, Masaki Kondo

item.title: Shell-Led LNG Canada Ships First Cargo to Meet Asian Demand
item.description: Shell Plc has started exports from Canada’s first liquefied natural gas project, helping to meet rising Asian demand and extending its position in the global LNG market.
item.dc:creator: Anna Shiryaevskaya, Mitchell Ferman, Ruth Liao

media:content.media:description: The LNG Canada facility in Kitimat, British Columbia. Photographer: Jennifer Gauthier/Bloomberg

item.title: Heavy Rainfall, Severe Weather Expected for Australia’s East Coast
item.description: Sydney could be be hit by more than a month’s worth of rain and severe weather in the coming days as an intense low-pressure system off the east coast batters the city, as well as regions already hit by extreme flooding this year.
item.dc:creator: Ben Westcott

item.title: Singapore Home Prices Rise for Third Quarter on Domestic Demand
item.description: Singapore private home prices rose for a third straight quarter, buoyed by local demand.
item.dc:creator: Dexter Low

item.title: Euro Hits Strongest Since 2014 Against Yuan as Rally Continues
item.description: The euro rallied to its strongest against the Chinese yuan in over a decade, buoyed by sustained capital inflows into the European market.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Zhu, Wenjin Lv

item.title: Natixis APAC CEO on Japan Branch Expansion
item.description: Bruno Le Saint, APAC CEO at Natixis CIB, discusses the firm's new banking branch establishment in Japan and says he aims to "double the number of employees for this business in the next 5-7 years". He speaks with Shery Ahn and Haidi Stroud Watts on "Bloomberg: The Asia Trade". (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Dai-ichi Life, Marubeni Aim to Hold $21 Billion in Real Estate
item.description: Dai-ichi Life Holdings Inc. said that it aims to hold ¥3 trillion ($21 billion) in real estate assets with Marubeni Corp. by the fiscal year starting April 2030 through the integration of their property businesses, making it among Japan’s biggest investors in the sector.
item.dc:creator: Nao Sano

media:content.media:description: Mount Fuji and the Shinjuku skyline in Tokyo. Photographer: Kiyoshi Ota/Bloomberg

item.title: Insurance Firm Accelerant Files for IPO, Disclosing Rising Sales
item.description: Accelerant Holdings filed for an initial public offering, joining a rush of insurance-related listings in the US.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Hughes

media:content.media:description: The New York Stock Exchange Photographer: Michael Nagle/Bloomberg

item.title: Robinhood Adds US Shares on the Blockchain | The Close 6/30/2025
item.description: Bloomberg Television brings you the latest news and analysis leading up to the final minutes and seconds before and after the closing bell on Wall Street. Today's guests are Jerome Schneider PIMCO, Vlad Tenev Robinhood CEO, Stefan Slowinski BNP PARIBAS EXANE, Ken Smetters University of Pennsylvania, Bob Mudguard Commonwealth Fusion Systems, Megan Horeman Verdence Capital, Jim Bianco Bianco Research, Bill Curtin Hogan Lovells, and Emily Stromquist Teneo. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: US Treasuries Get Vote of Confidence From Korea’s Wealth Fund
item.description: South Korea’s $206.5 billion sovereign wealth fund is standing by US Treasuries as a core holding, undeterred by recent market volatility.
item.dc:creator: David Ingles, Haram Lim, Jaehyun Eom

item.title: Struggling Semiconductor Firm Wolfspeed Files for Bankruptcy
item.description: Wolfspeed Inc., a chipmaker caught in President Donald Trump’s push to reshape Biden-era tech subsidies, filed bankruptcy to enact a creditor-backed plan to slash $4.6 billion in debt.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Randles, Steven Church

media:content.media:description: A Wolfspeed wafer Photographer: Boris Roessler/picture alliance/Getty Images
